Group.title: Kernel Parameters Which Affect Networking
Group.description: The sysctl utility is used to set parameters which affect the operation of the Linux kernel. Kernel parameters which affect networking and have security implications are described here.

Group.title: Network Parameters for Hosts Only
Group.description: If the system is not going to be used as a router, then setting certain kernel parameters ensure that the host will not perform routing of network traffic.

Rule.title: Disable Kernel Parameter for Sending ICMP Redirects by Default
Rule.rationale: Sending ICMP redirects permits the system to instruct other systems to update their routing information. The ability to send ICMP redirects is only appropriate for systems acting as routers.

Rule.title: Disable Kernel Parameter for Sending ICMP Redirects for All Interfaces
Rule.rationale: Sending ICMP redirects permits the system to instruct other systems to update their routing information. The ability to send ICMP redirects is only appropriate for systems acting as routers.

Rule.title: Disable Kernel Parameter for IP Forwarding
Rule.ocil: The ability to forward packets is only appropriate for routers.
Rule.rationale: IP forwarding permits the kernel to forward packets from one network interface to another. The ability to forward packets between two networks is only appropriate for systems acting as routers.

Group.title: Network Related Kernel Runtime Parameters for Hosts and Routers
Group.description: Certain kernel parameters should be set for systems which are acting as either hosts or routers to improve the system's ability defend against certain types of IPv4 protocol attacks.

Value.title: net.ipv4.conf.all.accept_source_route
Value.description: Trackers could be using source-routed packets to generate traffic that seems to be intra-net, but actually was created outside and has been redirected.

Value.title: net.ipv4.conf.all.secure_redirects
Value.description: Enable to prevent hijacking of routing path by only allowing redirects from gateways known in routing table.

Value.title: net.ipv4.conf.all.log_martians
Value.description: Disable so you don't Log Spoofed Packets, Source Routed Packets, Redirect Packets

Value.title: net.ipv4.conf.default.secure_redirects
Value.description: Log packets with impossible addresses to kernel log?

Value.title: net.ipv4.icmp_echo_ignore_broadcasts
Value.description: Ignore all ICMP ECHO and TIMESTAMP requests sent to it via broadcast/multicast

Value.title: net.ipv4.tcp_syncookies
Value.description: Enable to turn on TCP SYN Cookie Protection

Value.title: net.ipv4.conf.all.rp_filter
Value.description: Enable to enforce sanity checking, also called ingress filtering or egress filtering. The point is to drop a packet if the source and destination IP addresses in the IP header do not make sense when considered in light of the physical interface on which it arrived.

Rule.title: Configure Kernel Parameter for Accepting Source-Routed Packets for All Interfaces
Rule.rationale: Accepting source-routed packets in the IPv4 protocol has few legitimate uses. It should be disabled unless it is absolutely required.

Rule.title: Configure Kernel Parameter for Accepting ICMP Redirects for All Interfaces
Rule.rationale: Accepting ICMP redirects has few legitimate uses. It should be disabled unless it is absolutely required.

Rule.title: Configure Kernel Parameter for Accepting Secure Redirects for All Interfaces
Rule.rationale: Accepting "secure" ICMP redirects (from those gateways listed as default gateways) has few legitimate uses. It should be disabled unless it is absolutely required.

Rule.title: Configure Kernel Parameter to Log Martian Packets
Rule.rationale: The presence of "martian" packets (which have impossible addresses) as well as spoofed packets, source-routed packets, and redirects could be a sign of nefarious network activity. Logging these packets enables this activity to be detected.

Rule.title: Configure Kernel Parameter for Accepting Source-Routed Packets By Default
Rule.rationale: Accepting source-routed packets in the IPv4 protocol has few legitimate uses. It should be disabled unless it is absolutely required.

Rule.title: Configure Kernel Parameter for Accepting ICMP Redirects By Default
Rule.rationale: This feature of the IPv4 protocol has few legitimate uses. It should be disabled unless it is absolutely required.

Rule.title: Configure Kernel Parameter for Accepting Secure Redirects By Default
Rule.rationale: Accepting "secure" ICMP redirects (from those gateways listed as default gateways) has few legitimate uses. It should be disabled unless it is absolutely required.

Rule.title: Configure Kernel Parameter to Ignore ICMP Broadcast Echo Requests
Rule.rationale: Ignoring ICMP echo requests (pings) sent to broadcast or multicast addresses makes the system slightly more difficult to enumerate on the network.

Rule.title: Configure Kernel Parameter to Ignore Bogus ICMP Error Responses
Rule.rationale: Ignoring bogus ICMP error responses reduces log size, although some activity would not be logged.

Rule.title: Configure Kernel Parameter to Use TCP Syncookies
Rule.rationale: A TCP SYN flood attack can cause a denial of service by filling a system's TCP connection table with connections in the SYN_RCVD state. Syncookies can be used to track a connection when a subsequent ACK is received, verifying the initiator is attempting a valid connection and is not a flood source. This feature is activated when a flood condition is detected, and enables the system to continue servicing valid connection requests.

Rule.title: Configure Kernel Parameter to Use Reverse Path Filtering for All Interfaces
Rule.rationale: Enabling reverse path filtering drops packets with source addresses that should not have been able to be received on the interface they were received on. It should not be used on systems which are routers for complicated networks, but is helpful for end hosts and routers serving small networks.

Rule.title: Configure Kernel Parameter to Use Reverse Path Filtering by Default
Rule.rationale: Enabling reverse path filtering drops packets with source addresses that should not have been able to be received on the interface they were received on. It should not be used on systems which are routers for complicated networks, but is helpful for end hosts and routers serving small networks.
